citation: Silberberger, M. J., Renaud, P. E., Buhl-Mortensen, L., Ellingsen, I. H., & Reiss, H. (2018). Spatial patterns in sub-Arctic benthos: multiscale analysis reveals structural differences between community components. Ecological Monographs, 89(1), e01325. doi:10.1002/ecm.1325
description: Used PCA to identify spatial patterns in community data. RDA and PERMANOVA used for multivariate hypothesis testing.
notes: partial RDA used to account for random effects

citation: Fuiman, L. A. (2018). Egg boon fatty acids reveal effects of a climatic event on a marine food web. Ecological Monographs, 88(4), 585–599. doi:10.1002/ecm.1324
description: PCA on fatty acid profiles. Resulting PCs used as predictors in ANOVA
notes: "Patterns of variation in complete egg fatty acid profiles were summarized by principal components analysis (PCA), which reduced the 23 fatty acid variables to a smaller number of independent factors."

citation: Wetzel, W. C., Aflitto, N. C., & Thaler, J. S. (2018). Plant genotypic diversity interacts with predation risk to influence an insect herbivore across its ontogeny. Ecology, 99(10), 2338–2347. doi:10.1002/ecy.2472
description: PCA on two growth variables. PC1 used as response variable in linear mixed effects models
notes: PCA on two variables because they were correlated.

citation: Champagnon, J., Lebreton, J., Drummond, H., & Anderson, D. J. (2018). Pacific Decadal and El Niño oscillations shape survival of a seabird. Ecology, 99(5), 1063–1072. doi:10.1002/ecy.2179
description: PCA on 7 environmental parameters. Two PCs used as predictors in analysis of deviance (ANODEV)
notes: almsot definitely could have used PLS

citation: Preston, D. L., Henderson, J. S., Falke, L. P., Segui, L. M., Layden, T. J., & Novak, M. (2018). What drives interaction strengths in complex food webs? A test with feeding rates of a generalist stream predator. Ecology, 99(7), 1591–1601. doi:10.1002/ecy.2387
description: PCA on 5 abiotic variables. Used PC1 as predictor in a GAMM
notes: "The primary aim of our analysis was to determine the relative importance of prey density, predator density, predator‚Äêprey body mass ratios, prey identity (i.e., taxonomic order), and abiotic environmental variables in driving variation in prey‚Äêspecific sculpin feeding rates. " (abiotic variables are summarized with PCA)

citation: Matsuzaki, S. S., Suzuki, K., Kadoya, T., Nakagawa, M., & Takamura, N. (2018). Bottom-up linkages between primary production, zooplankton, and fish in a shallow, hypereutrophic lake. Ecology, 99(9), 2025–2036. doi:10.1002/ecy.2414
description: PCA on biovolume of 4 plankton groups. PC1 used in convergent cross-mapping (CCM)
notes: The authors want to know if phytoplankton community composition (PC1) is a driver of productivity.

citation: Li, Y., & Shipley, B. (2018). Community divergence and convergence along experimental gradients of stress and disturbance. Ecology, 99(4), 775–781. doi:10.1002/ecy.2162
pca_use: PCA space used to create distance-based variable
description: PCA on 15 functional traits. Four PCs used to calculate functional dissimilarity, which in turn is used as a predictor in an ANOVA
notes: They use PCA to make a "trait space", then project species onto it, then calculate distance between pairs, then ask if that distance is affected by a treatment

citation: Nottingham, A. T., Fierer, N., Turner, B. L., Whitaker, J., Ostle, N. J., McNamara, N. P., … Meir, P. (2018). Microbes follow Humboldt: temperature drives plant and soil microbial diversity patterns from the Amazon to the Andes. Ecology, 99(11), 2455–2466. doi:10.1002/ecy.2482
description: Unclear what PCA is used for. Mentioned only briefly in methods. Supervised methods used to test hypotheses

citation: Robinson, M. L., & Strauss, S. Y. (2018). Cascading effects of soil type on assemblage size and structure in a diverse herbivore community. Ecology, 99(8), 1866–1877. doi:10.1002/ecy.2406
description: PCA on 7 leaf traits to identify major axes of variation. PCs used in linear mixed effects models
notes: PCA used to create axes of plant traits, but no a priori biological relevance.

citation: Roscher, C., Schumacher, J., Lipowsky, A., Gubsch, M., Weigelt, A., Schmid, B., … Schulze, E.-D. (2018). Functional groups differ in trait means, but not in trait plasticity to species richness in local grassland communities. Ecology, 99(10), 2295–2307. doi:10.1002/ecy.2447
description: PCA on 10 trait variables to visualize spearation in trait-space.
notes: Researchers used many univariate ANOVAs to test hypotheses. PCA was used just for visualizing differences, but they do discuss separation in PCA space.  A supervised multivariate analysis may have been more appropriate.

citation: Tiede, Y., Hemp, C., Schmidt, A., Nauss, T., Farwig, N., & Brandl, R. (2018). Beyond body size: consistent decrease of traits within orthopteran assemblages with elevation. Ecology, 99(9), 2090–2102. doi:10.1002/ecy.2436
description: PCA on 10 morphological traits.PC1 standardized by body size, then used in linear regressions
notes: Authors justify PCA on body size traits as being important if you want to make comparisons among taxa from different familes.

citation: Parker, T. C., Sanderman, J., Holden, R. D., Blume-Werry, G., Sjögersten, S., Large, D., … Wookey, P. A. (2018). Exploring drivers of litter decomposition in a greening Arctic: results from a transplant experiment across a treeline. Ecology, 99(10), 2284–2294. doi:10.1002/ecy.2442
description: PLS used for predicting NMR chemical shift regions from FTIR data

citation: Hausch, S., Vamosi, S. M., & Fox, J. W. (2018). Effects of intraspecific phenotypic variation on species coexistence. Ecology, 99(6), 1453–1462. doi:10.1002/ecy.2346
description: PCA on 9 traits. Three PC axes used for visualizing differences among species

citation: Defossez, E., Pellissier, L., & Rasmann, S. (2018). The unfolding of plant growth form-defence syndromes along elevation gradients. Ecology Letters, 21(5), 609–618. doi:10.1111/ele.12926
description: PCA on 10 traits. Biplot of first 2 PCs used to inform a system of describing plants with polygons on radial plots. These polygons used in further analyses.

citation: Hodge, J. R., Alim, C., Bertrand, N. G., Lee, W., Price, S. A., Tran, B., & Wainwright, P. C. (2018). Ecology shapes the evolutionary trade-off between predator avoidance and defence in coral reef butterflyfishes. Ecology Letters, 21(7), 1033–1042. doi:10.1111/ele.12969
description: Phylogenetic PCA on seven morphological traits. Used to visualize morphological differences among species with different foraging regimes.
notes: The authors seem interested in testing the hypothesis that species with different foraging behaviors have different morphology, but they didn't do so using any multivariate methods.

citation: Schermer, É., Bel‐Venner, M., Fouchet, D., Siberchicot, A., Boulanger, V., Caignard, T., … Venner, S. (2018). Pollen limitation as a main driver of fruiting dynamics in oak populations. Ecology Letters, 22(1), 98–107. doi:10.1111/ele.13171
description: PCA on two variables (rain and temperature). PC1 used as predictor in GLMM
notes: PCA on only 2 variables (rain and temp) for each month to get a "weather index" for each month.

citation: Jucker, T., Bongalov, B., Burslem, D. F. R. P., Nilus, R., Dalponte, M., Lewis, S. L., … Coomes, D. A. (2018). Topography shapes the structure, composition and function of tropical forest landscapes. Ecology Letters, 21(7), 989–1000. doi:10.1111/ele.12964
description: PCA on 4 topography variables. PCA used to visualize data. PLSR used to predict species richness from remote sensing data.
notes: PCA just used for visualizing data, PLSR used in a predictive way

citation: Chira, A. M., Cooney, C. R., Bright, J. A., Capp, E. J. R., Hughes, E. C., Moody, C. J. A., … Thomas, G. H. (2018). Correlates of rate heterogeneity in avian ecomorphological traits. Ecology Letters, 21(10), 1505–1514. doi:10.1111/ele.13131
pca_use: PCA space used to create distance-based variable
description: Principal PCA on morphological data. Used 8 PCs to measure euclidean distance between clades

citation: Rüger, N., Comita, L. S., Condit, R., Purves, D., Rosenbaum, B., Visser, M. D., … Wirth, C. (2018). Beyond the fast-slow continuum: demographic dimensions structuring a tropical tree community. Ecology Letters, 21(7), 1075–1084. doi:10.1111/ele.12974
description: Weighted PCA on 9 demographic variables. Data visualized with bi-plots.

citation: Anderegg, L. D. L., Berner, L. T., Badgley, G., Sethi, M. L., Law, B. E., & HilleRisLambers, J. (2018). Within-species patterns challenge our understanding of the leaf economics spectrum. Ecology Letters, 21(5), 734–744. doi:10.1111/ele.12945
description: PCA on 7 climate variables. Used as predictors in linear mixed effects models.
notes: this study also has multivariate plant trait data, but no multivariate methods are used for those data.

citation: Prather, C. M., Laws, A. N., Cuellar, J. F., Reihart, R. W., Gawkins, K. M., & Pennings, S. C. (2018). Seeking salt: herbivorous prairie insects can be co-limited by macronutrients and sodium. Ecology Letters, 21(10), 1467–1476. doi:10.1111/ele.13127
description: PCA on the abundance of 6 species. Biplot used to visualize clustering of species by soil nutrients.
notes: Although this is strictly an unsupervised use, the authors do discuss effects of soil nutrients on species communities using the PCA as evidence

citation: Chu, C., Lutz, J. A., Král, K., Vrška, T., Yin, X., Myers, J. A., … Burslem, D. F. R. P. (2018). Direct and indirect effects of climate on richness drive the latitudinal diversity gradient in forest trees. Ecology Letters. doi:10.1111/ele.13175
description: PCAs on 21 climate and topography variables at two spatial scales (across the whole dataset, and within plot PCAs). Two PCs used as predictors in structural equation modeling

citation: Di Marco, M., Watson, J. E. M., Currie, D. J., Possingham, H. P., & Venter, O. (2018). The extent and predictability of the biodiversity-carbon correlation. Ecology Letters, 21(3), 365–375. doi:10.1111/ele.12903
description: PCA on 6 WorldClim variables. Two PCs retained.PCA on 7 soil variables. Two PCs retained.PCs used as predictors in spatial simultaneous autoregressive error models.

citation: Decker, L. E., de Roode, J. C., & Hunter, M. D. (2018). Elevated atmospheric concentrations of carbon dioxide reduce monarch tolerance and increase parasite virulence by altering the medicinal properties of milkweeds. Ecology Letters, 21(9), 1353–1363. doi:10.1111/ele.13101
description: PCA on centered-log-ratio transformed cardenolide concentrations. Two PCs used as predictors in linear mixed effects models.
notes: Partial RDA would have been a good choice here.

citation: Walker, T. W. N., Weckwerth, W., Bragazza, L., Fragner, L., Forde, B. G., Ostle, N. J., … Bardgett, R. D. (2018). Plastic and genetic responses of a common sedge to warming have contrasting effects on carbon cycle processes. Ecology Letters, 22(1), 159–169. doi:10.1111/ele.13178
description: Unclear how PCA is used. It is not mentioned in the methods. RDA and PERMANOVA are used for hypothesis testing.
notes: PCA not mentioned in methods, only in figure captions.

citation: Ye, C., Chen, D., Hall, S. J., Pan, S., Yan, X., Bai, T., … Hu, S. (2018). Reconciling multiple impacts of nitrogen enrichment on soil carbon: plant, microbial and geochemical controls. Ecology Letters, 21(8), 1162–1173. doi:10.1111/ele.13083
description: PCA on concentrations of two forms of nitrogen. First PC used as predictor in SEM

citation: Simpson, R. K., & McGraw, K. J. (2018). It’s not just what you have, but how you use it: solar-positional and behavioural effects on hummingbird colour appearance during courtship. Ecology Letters, 21(9), 1413–1422. doi:10.1111/ele.13125
description: PCAs on feather color traits. PCs used as predictors in linear mixed effects models.
notes: "We were unable to neatly compact the four measures of feather reflectance using principal components analysis (PCA), but could collapse angle dependence in luminance, chroma and UV hue into a single principal component "

citation: Carrillo, Y., Dijkstra, F., LeCain, D., Blumenthal, D., & Pendall, E. (2018). Elevated CO2 and warming cause interactive effects on soil carbon and shifts in carbon use by bacteria. Ecology Letters, 21(11), 1639–1648. doi:10.1111/ele.13140
description: PCA on phospholipid fatty acid composition of microbial community in soils. PCs used as as response variable in ANOVA.
notes: "Effects of treatments on PLFA profiles were analysed with principal component analysis (PCA) on correlations and two-factor anova on PCs."

citation: Ruegg, K., Bay, R. A., Anderson, E. C., Saracco, J. F., Harrigan, R. J., Whitfield, M., … Smith, T. B. (2018). Ecological genomics predicts climate vulnerability in an endangered southwestern songbird. Ecology Letters, 21(7), 1085–1096. doi:10.1111/ele.12977
description: PCA used to summarize and visualize results from a Gradient Forest Analysis
notes: Gradient Forest analysis is an extension of random forests that works with continuous response variables like environmental gradients (https://esajournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/pdf/10.1890/11-0252.1)

citation: Jeffers, E. S., Whitehouse, N. J., Lister, A., Plunkett, G., Barratt, P., Smyth, E., … Bonsall, M. B. (2018). Plant controls on Late Quaternary whole ecosystem structure and function. Ecology Letters, 21(6), 814–825. doi:10.1111/ele.12944
description: Uses weighted average PLS (WA-PLS) to predict july air temp from Chironomid assemblages.
notes: "Chironomid assemblages were translated into mean July air temperatures with a three‚Äêcomponent WA‚ÄêPLS transfer function based on a 153‚Äêlake modern Norwegian chironomid training set (Brooks & Birks 2001; Heiri et al. 2011)."

citation: Toussaint, A., Charpin, N., Beauchard, O., Grenouillet, G., Oberdorff, T., Tedesco, P. A., … Villéger, S. (2018). Non-native species led to marked shifts in functional diversity of the world freshwater fish faunas. Ecology Letters, 21(11), 1649–1659. doi:10.1111/ele.13141
pca_use: PCA space used to create distance-based variable, unsupervised (supervised question)
description: PCA on 10 functional traits. Used 5 PCs as a trait space. Measured distances between species in this trait-space.
notes: In the methods, they describe mostly unsupervised uses of PCA, but in the results they say "Non-native species introduction tends to increase average fish body size (Blanchet et al. 2010) and reduce body elongation in all realms (see PC4 on Figs 4 and S5 and Tables S1 and S4). " which would be better answered with a supervised approach.

citation: Biasazin, T. D., Larsson Herrera, S., Kimbokota, F., & Dekker, T. (2018). Translating olfactomes into attractants: shared volatiles provide attractive bridges for polyphagy in fruit flies. Ecology Letters, 22(1), 108–118. doi:10.1111/ele.13172
description: NMDS and PCA used to determine if different species of flies respond differently to fruit volatiles using GC-EAD. Clustering in bi-plots interpreted directly as evidence for distinct responses from different species
notes: results focus on the fact that flies respond to volatiles that are common across fruit species, but multivariate analyses seem to focus on differences among fly species within fruits.

citation: Penone, C., Allan, E., Soliveres, S., Felipe‐Lucia, M. R., Gossner, M. M., Seibold, S., … Fischer, M. (2018). Specialisation and diversity of multiple trophic groups are promoted by different forest features. Ecology Letters, 22(1), 170–180. doi:10.1111/ele.13182
description: PCA on 8 soil parameters. Two PCs used as co-variates along with 9 other forest feature variables in a total of 60 linear regression models (4 response variables x 15 trophic groups)
notes: justifies not using multivariate methods by testing for collinearity, and doing false discovery rate corrections to p-values. Could have benefitted from supervised multivariate methods.

citation: Chadwick, K. D., & Asner, G. P. (2018). Landscape evolution and nutrient rejuvenation reflected in Amazon forest canopy chemistry. Ecology Letters, 21(7), 978–988. doi:10.1111/ele.12963
description: PLSR used to predict plant traits from remote sensing data. Authors collected their own data from a subset of trees to train a PLSR model.

citation: Ohlmann, M., Mazel, F., Chalmandrier, L., Bec, S., Coissac, E., Gielly, L., … Thuiller, W. (2018). Mapping the imprint of biotic interactions on β-diversity. Ecology Letters, 21(11), 1660–1669. doi:10.1111/ele.13143
pca_use: PCA space used to create distance-based variable
description: PCA on climate and soil parameters. First two PCs used to measure environmental distance between sites. Environmental distance used as a co-variate in graphical lasso method

citation: Garnier, E., Fayolle, A., Navas, M.-L., Damgaard, C., Cruz, P., Hubert, D., … Violle, C. (2018). Plant demographic and functional responses to management intensification: A long-term study in a Mediterranean rangeland. Journal of Ecology, 106(4), 1363–1376. doi:10.1111/1365-2745.12996
description: PCA on 9 traits. Two PCs used in ANOVA
notes: In addition to doing PCR, they did univariate tests for each trait.

citation: Umaña, M. N., Zipkin, E. F., Zhang, C., Cao, M., Lin, L., & Swenson, N. G. (2018). Individual-level trait variation and negative density dependence affect growth in tropical tree seedlings. Journal of Ecology, 106(6), 2446–2455. doi:10.1111/1365-2745.13001
pca_use: PCA space used to create distance-based variable
description: PCA on species traits, retainted 3 PCS, then reduced data further by calculating a mean euclidean distance between points (trait dissimilarity).Used trait dissimilarity and the 3 pcs as predictors in a JAGS model with relative growth rate as a response.
notes: The euclidean distance calculation is an unsupervised use since they wanted a variable that represented trait dissimilarity.

citation: Gustafsson, C., & Norkko, A. (2018). Quantifying the importance of functional traits for primary production in aquatic plant communities. Journal of Ecology, 107(1), 154–166. doi:10.1111/1365-2745.13011
description: PCA on environmental variables. Used to describe / cluster sites by a gradient of wave exposure (the authors interpretation of the first PC). Supervised methods used to test differences in community or trait differences among sites.

citation: Padullés Cubino, J., Buckley, H. L., Day, N. J., Pieper, R., & Curran, T. J. (2018). Community-level flammability declines over 25 years of plant invasion in grasslands. Journal of Ecology, 106(4), 1582–1594. doi:10.1111/1365-2745.12933
description: PCA on 4 traits related to flamability. A second PCA on the 4 flamability traits plus 9 morphological traits.Used correlation tests to determine which morphological traits were associated with flamability PCs and in linear mixed effects models to model change in flamability over time.
notes: PLS with multiple Y variables (flamability traits) and multiple X variables (morphological traits) would be a good fit for this analylsis.

citation: Levy, P., Dijk, N., Gray, A., Sutton, M., Jones, M., Leeson, S., … Sheppard, L. (2018). Response of a peat bog vegetation community to long‐term experimental addition of nitrogen. Journal of Ecology, 107(3), 1167–1186. doi:10.1111/1365-2745.13107
description: Used PLS to test for co-variation of species composition with porewater chemistry
notes: "In the case of PLS, we established an axis which described the multivariate variation in species composition along the NH3 gradient, and related this to the porewater chemistry " Also used princinpal response curvesd analysis, which is a variant of RDA.

citation: Leunda, M., González-Sampériz, P., Gil-Romera, G., Bartolomé, M., Belmonte-Ribas, Á., Gómez-García, D., … Sancho, C. (2018). Ice cave reveals environmental forcing of long-term Pyrenean tree line dynamics. Journal of Ecology, 107(2), 814–828. doi:10.1111/1365-2745.13077
description: PCA on pollen percentages from ice cores. Used to visualize community level changes over time.
notes: "We identified the underlying gradients in regional vegetation composition over time applying ordination analyses to the pollen percentage dataset".  Because they are intersted in change in composition over time, this seems appropriate.  However, if they asked "which plant species change over time", this would be better answered by PLS.

citation: Benito, X., Fritz, S. C., Steinitz-Kannan, M., Tapia, P. M., Kelly, M. A., & Lowell, T. V. (2018). Geo-climatic factors drive diatom community distribution in tropical South American freshwaters. Journal of Ecology, 106(4), 1660–1672. doi:10.1111/1365-2745.12934
description: PCA on 12 geo-climatic and two limnological variables. PERMANOVA used to test for differences in diatom composition between regions.NMDS used to ordinate diatom communities, then tested for relationship with geo-climatic predictor variables using envfit() function in the vegan package for R.
notes: The envfit() function, I believe, is doing something analagous to principal component regression.

citation: Hagenbo, A., Kyaschenko, J., Clemmensen, K. E., Lindahl, B. D., & Fransson, P. (2018). Fungal community shifts underpin declining mycelial production and turnover across a Pinus sylvestris chronosequence. Journal of Ecology, 106(2), 490–501. doi:10.1111/1365-2745.12917
description: PLS used to test for relationship between biomass and ITS2 copy number of fungal groups with incubation time as a co-variate.
notes: "Partial least squares regression (PLS) was run using the NIPALS algorithm (PROC PLS) in SAS 9.4 (SAS Institute Inc., Cary, NC, USA) to test whether ergosterol-based biomass estimates could be explained by mesh bag incubation time or ITS2 copy numbers (square root transformed to achieve linearity) of individual fungal functional groups"

citation: Lozano, Y. M., Hortal, S., Armas, C., & Pugnaire, F. I. (2018). Soil micro‐organisms and competitive ability of a tussock grass species in a dry ecosystem. Journal of Ecology, 107(3), 1215–1225. doi:10.1111/1365-2745.13104
description: PCA on relative abundances of soil bacteria and soil chemistry. Bi-plot used to look for separation in communities
notes: "Ordination by PCA based on relative abundance of soil bacterial phyla and soil properties at the start of the experiment (i.e., field soils prior to soil sterilization) showed a clear separation between Lygeum and Salsola soil communities (Figure 5), with the first two axes explaining 67.71% of the total variance. "

citation: Martinez, K. A., & Fridley, J. D. (2018). Acclimation of leaf traits in seasonal light environments: Are non-native species more plastic? Journal of Ecology, 106(5), 2019–2030. doi:10.1111/1365-2745.12952
description: Used parameters derived from bayesian model posteriors as variables in PCA. PCA along with Hotelling tests used to test for difference in leaf traits between species and among seasons.
notes: "Mean values of the posterior distributions of the above parameters were used in linear models to analyse seasonal trait plasticity and in a principal component analysis (PCA) incorporating laboratory-measured leaf traits." "To compare suites of leaf traits between nativity groups and across seasons, we performed a PCA on ranked values of all leaf traits and photosynthetic parameters. Multivariate inference was based on Hotelling tests for season, nativity and their interaction, and post hoc corrections on individual leaf traits included Hochberg's test (Curran, 2017)."

citation: Satdichanh, M., Ma, H., Yan, K., Dossa, G. G. O., Winowiecki, L., Vågen, T., … Harrison, R. D. (2018). Phylogenetic diversity correlated with above‐ground biomass production during forest succession: Evidence from tropical forests in Southeast Asia. Journal of Ecology, 107(3), 1419–1432. doi:10.1111/1365-2745.13112
description: PCA on 7 soil parameters. Three PCs used in correlation tests with net relatedness index.Used PCs as co-variates in structural equation models to test for associations with above ground biomass
notes: "Principle component analysis was applied on the seven selected soil fertility parameters from each site to reduce the number of parameters. "

citation: Duffin, K. I., Li, S., & Meiners, S. J. (2018). Species pools and differential performance generate variation in leaf nutrients between native and exotic species in succession. Journal of Ecology, 107(2), 595–605. doi:10.1111/1365-2745.13043
description: PCA on 6 leaf nutrients. Bi-plot of first two PCs used to visualize data only. Hypothesis testing done with MANOVA
notes: "Analyses revolved around identifying species pool and differential performance-based variation between native and exotic species in succession."

citation: Zhou, M., Bai, W., Zhang, Y., & Zhang, W.-H. (2018). Multi-dimensional patterns of variation in root traits among coexisting herbaceous species in temperate steppes. Journal of Ecology, 106(6), 2320–2331. doi:10.1111/1365-2745.12977
description: PCA to extract main axes of variation in root traits. Used to test whether a single-axis "root economics spectrum" exists. They found three axes that explained a large proportion of variation rather than one.
notes: "The main variation axis of root traits was detected by PCA"

citation: Hegstad, R. J., & Maron, J. L. (2018). Productivity and related soil properties mediate the population‐level consequences of rodent seed predation on Blanketflower,Gaillardia aristata. Journal of Ecology, 107(1), 34–44. doi:10.1111/1365-2745.13020
pca_use: PC(s) used in LMM, PC(s) used in LM, PC(s) used in ANCOVA
description: PCA on 8 vegetation and soil variables. Two PCs used as predictors in regressions, linear mixed effects models and Analysis of Covariance (ANCOVA).
notes: "We conducted a principle component analysis (using prcomp; base R) to reduce site productivity and soil measurements into several multivariate axes. "

citation: Erktan, A., Roumet, C., Bouchet, D., Stokes, A., Pailler, F., & Munoz, F. (2018). Two dimensions define the variation of fine root traits across plant communities under the joint influence of ecological succession and annual mowing. Journal of Ecology, 106(5), 2031–2042. doi:10.1111/1365-2745.12953
description: PCA on 6 root traits separately for mown and unmown communities. Used PCA bi-plots to see how root traits change with succession.
notes: If they wanted to know which root traits vary with succession, a supervised method would have been more appropriate. RDA, for example, could test for the joint effects of mowing and succession (and interactions) on root traits.

citation: Kleyer, M., Trinogga, J., Cebrián-Piqueras, M. A., Trenkamp, A., Fløjgaard, C., Ejrnaes, R., … Blasius, B. (2018). Trait correlation network analysis identifies biomass allocation traits and stem specific length as hub traits in herbaceous perennial plants. Journal of Ecology, 107(2), 829–842. doi:10.1111/1365-2745.13066
description: Used heirarcical clustering to identify traits belonging to clusters.Individual PCAs on those groups of traits to determine "module values"
notes: "Using modules, that is, PCA scores of highly connected trait clusters, as response-traits‚Äù may be helpful to reduce the effects of multicollinearity imposed by trait correlations."

citation: Carvajal, D. E., Loayza, A. P., Rios, R. S., Delpiano, C. A., & Squeo, F. A. (2018). A hyper‐arid environment shapes an inverse pattern of the fast–slow plant economics spectrum for above‐, but not below‐ground resource acquisition strategies. Journal of Ecology, 107(3), 1079–1092. doi:10.1111/1365-2745.13092
description: PCA on leaf traits. PC1 used as a proxy for plant economics spectrum as a predictor in several regressions
notes: "To evaluate the shift in the functional structure of shrub assemblages in different plant organs along the aridity gradient, we performed separate principal component analyses (PCAs) for leaf and root traits. "

citation: Bezemer, T. M., Jing, J., Bakx-Schotman, J. M. T., & Bijleveld, E.-J. (2018). Plant competition alters the temporal dynamics of plant-soil feedbacks. Journal of Ecology, 106(6), 2287–2300. doi:10.1111/1365-2745.12999
description: PCA used for visualizing data. Supervised methods used for hypothesis testing.

citation: Feng, Y., Fouqueray, T. D., & van Kleunen, M. (2018). Linking Darwin’s naturalisation hypothesis and Elton’s diversity-invasibility hypothesis in experimental grassland communities. Journal of Ecology, 107(2), 794–805. doi:10.1111/1365-2745.13061
pca_use: PCA space used to create distance-based variable
description: PCA on two functional traits of several plant species. Three PCs used in calculations of functional distance and functional diversity. These are in turn used as predictor variables in GLMMs
notes: "we did principal component analysis (PCA) to get orthogonal trait axes, and used the resulting three PCA axes to do the FDist and FDiv calculations."In this paper, the hypotheses center around functional differences in communities, so using PCA in this way makes sense to me.

citation: Zambrano, J., Fagan, W. F., Worthy, S. J., Thompson, J., Uriarte, M., Zimmerman, J. K., … Swenson, N. G. (2018). Tree crown overlap improves predictions of the functional neighbourhood effects on tree survival and growth. Journal of Ecology, 107(2), 887–900. doi:10.1111/1365-2745.13075
pca_use: PC(s) used in bayesian heirarchical analysis
description: PCA on 8 functional plant traits. Two PCs used as predictors in bayesian heirarchical analysis run in JAGS

citation: Sakaguchi, S., Horie, K., Ishikawa, N., Nishio, S., Worth, J. R. P., Fukushima, K., … Ito, M. (2018). Maintenance of soil ecotypes ofSolidago virgaureain close parapatry via divergent flowering time and selection against immigrants. Journal of Ecology, 107(1), 418–435. doi:10.1111/1365-2745.13034
description: PCA on genetic marker data. Plot of first two PCs used to visualize differentiation between sites and ecotypes.
notes: "Another driver of population genetic differentiation of the Solidago populations was geography, as the two regional populations were well-separated along the first PCA axis (FST = 0.047‚Äì0.050; Supporting Information Figure S1). " This seems like it would be better approached with a supervised method.

citation: Beckman, N. G., Bullock, J. M., & Salguero-Gómez, R. (2018). High dispersal ability is related to fast life-history strategies. Journal of Ecology, 106(4), 1349–1362. doi:10.1111/1365-2745.12989
description: PCAs on plant traits with and without dispersal ability included. Described changes in loadings of three PCs to describe the relationship between plant functional traits and dispersal ability.
notes: A primary goal of the study was to determine which plant functional traits relate to dispersal ability. To this end they performed PCA with and without dispersal ability and looked at how the loadings changed. This is definitely a situation where the authors could have benefitted from using a supervised approach like PLS or RDA which return loadings.

citation: Barbe, L., Mony, C., Jung, V., Santonja, M., Bartish, I., & Prinzing, A. (2018). Functionally or phylogenetically distinct neighbours turn antagonism among decomposing litter species into synergy. Journal of Ecology, 106(4), 1401–1414. doi:10.1111/1365-2745.12944
description: PCA on 4 litter traits.  Used to visualize data only

citation: Draper, F. C., Baraloto, C., Brodrick, P. G., Phillips, O. L., Martinez, R. V., Honorio Coronado, E. N., … Asner, G. P. (2018). Imaging spectroscopy predicts variable distance decay across contrasting Amazonian tree communities. Journal of Ecology, 107(2), 696–710. doi:10.1111/1365-2745.13067
description: PCA on processed spectral image data. Looked at 35 PCs, discarded any that captured background or artifacts.  Resulted in 4–8 useful PCs. PCs used in k-means clustering to cluster pixels into one of 50 groups to flatten multi-layer image into single layer image.
notes: "We performed a principal component analysis (PCA) on our processed spectral image in order to reduce the high dimensionality of the spectral data and to isolate and remove sampling artefacts such as cross‐track brightness gradients."

citation: Barbour, M. A., Erlandson, S., Peay, K., Locke, B., Jules, E. S., & Crutsinger, G. M. (2018). Trait plasticity is more important than genetic variation in determining species richness of associated communities. Journal of Ecology, 107(1), 350–360. doi:10.1111/1365-2745.13014
description: PCA on 9 plant traits separately for each year of experiment. PCs used as predictors in linear mixed-effects models to test for relationship with arthropod richness.
notes: "We used principal components analysis (PCA) to condense above‐ground willow traits into a small number of uncorrelated variables. This step was necessary to eliminate collinearity among traits, which could make it difficult to interpret subsequent analyses of intraspecific effects on associated communities."

citation: Hapsari, K. A., Biagioni, S., Jennerjahn, T. C., Reimer, P., Saad, A., Sabiham, S., & Behling, H. (2018). Resilience of a peatland in Central Sumatra, Indonesia to past anthropogenic disturbance: Improving conservation and restoration designs using palaeoecology. Journal of Ecology, 106(6), 2473–2490. doi:10.1111/1365-2745.13000
description: PCA on pollen composition of soil cores. Used to visualize change in vegetation over time.
notes: "Principle component analysis results based on pollen and spore data demonstrate the characteristics of taxa assemblage and reveal changes in vegetation over time (Figure 6). "

citation: Castagneyrol, B., Jactel, H., & Moreira, X. (2018). Anti-herbivore defences and insect herbivory: Interactive effects of drought and tree neighbours. Journal of Ecology, 106(5), 2043–2057. doi:10.1111/1365-2745.12956
description: PCA on 6 leaf traits. Used in linear mixed effects models as response variables.  In addition, researchers conducted separate LMER for each of the 6 traits.
notes: This would be a good candidate for partial RDA

citation: Harrison, J. G., Parchman, T. L., Cook, D., Gardner, D. R., & Forister, M. L. (2018). A heritable symbiont and host-associated factors shape fungal endophyte communities across spatial scales. Journal of Ecology, 106(6), 2274–2286. doi:10.1111/1365-2745.12967
description: PCA on 13,366 SNPs collected from locoweed individuals.  MDS on fungal community of plants (287 OTUs). Another PCA on 9 soil variables.  Raw abundances of fungal OTUs used in multiple regression.
notes: "We used multiple regression to investigate the predictors of fungal richness, diversity and average between‐plant turnover among locoweed populations. "  Because of the problems in collinearity of predictors that they've acknowledged, PLS regression might be a better option for answering this qustion

citation: Maron, J. L., Hajek, K. L., Hahn, P. G., & Pearson, D. E. (2018). Rodent seed predators and a dominant grass competitor affect coexistence of co-occurring forb species that vary in seed size. Journal of Ecology, 106(5), 1795–1805. doi:10.1111/1365-2745.13027
description: PCA on 4 plant functional traits. First PC used in linear mixed effects models.
notes: "In order to determine whether seed size covaried with the other functional traits we measured, we performed a principle components analysis (PCA) using the prcomp function in r (R Core Team, 2017). The analysis used the correlation matrix of the traits."  Authors are explicitly looking to explain co-variation with a response variable but use an unsupervised method (PCA)

citation: Borges, I. L., Forsyth, L. Z., Start, D., & Gilbert, B. (2018). Abiotic heterogeneity underlies trait-based competition and assembly. Journal of Ecology, 107(2), 747–756. doi:10.1111/1365-2745.13082
description: PCA on 12 soil variables. 3 PCs used as predictors in generalized linear mixed effects models with a binomial error distribution.

citation: Blonder, B., Kapas, R. E., Dalton, R. M., Graae, B. J., Heiling, J. M., & Opedal, Ø. H. (2018). Microenvironment and functional-trait context dependence predict alpine plant community dynamics. Journal of Ecology, 106(4), 1323–1337. doi:10.1111/1365-2745.12973
description: PCA on 17 microenvironmental traits. PCs with eigenvalues > 1 used to determine realized niche of species as location of centriod for each species. Used as response in linear mixed effects models. Separate PCA on 20+ plant traits. PCs used as predictors in those mixed effects models.
notes: Might be better answered with procrustes analysis or PLS using all microenvironment traits as the Y variable and plant traits as X.

citation: Sangüesa-Barreda, G., Camarero, J. J., Pironon, S., Gazol, A., Peguero-Pina, J. J., & Gil-Pelegrín, E. (2018). Delineating limits: Confronting predicted climatic suitability to field performance in mistletoe populations. Journal of Ecology, 106(6), 2218–2229. doi:10.1111/1365-2745.12968
description: PCA used to select orthogonal WorldClim variables.
notes: "We reduced multicollinearity among the 19 bioclimatic variables provided by Worldclim by using principal component analysis and correlation matrix analyses (results not shown). We selected the following five variables: temperature seasonality (BIO4), mean temperature of the wettest (BIO8) and coldest (BIO11) quarters, precipitation of the driest (BIO17) and coldest (BIO19) quarters."

citation: Visser, M. D., Muller-Landau, H. C., Schnitzer, S. A., de Kroon, H., Jongejans, E., & Wright, S. J. (2018). A host-parasite model explains variation in liana infestation among co-occurring tree species. Journal of Ecology, 106(6), 2435–2445. doi:10.1111/1365-2745.12997
pca_use: PC(s) used in SEM, PC(s) used in correlation test
description: PCA on 5 traits related to shade tolerance.  First PC used as a shade intolerance index used in correlation analyses.  A second approach uses "multivariate latent variable analysis using structural equation models (SEMs)" where shade intolerance is modeled as a latent variable.

citation: Rolhauser, A. G., Nordenstahl, M., Aguiar, M. R., & Pucheta, E. (2018). Community-level natural selection modes: A quadratic framework to link multiple functional traits with competitive ability. Journal of Ecology, 107(3), 1457–1468. doi:10.1111/1365-2745.13094
description: PCA on 8 functional plant traits. 3 PCs used as predictors in linear mixed effects models.  In addition, a model was built using 7 of these plant traits (the model with best AIC).

citation: Barks, P. M., Dempsey, Z. W., Burg, T. M., & Laird, R. A. (2018). Among-strain consistency in the pace and shape of senescence in duckweed. Journal of Ecology, 106(5), 2132–2145. doi:10.1111/1365-2745.12937
pca_use: PC(s) used in bayesian heirarchical analysis
description: PCA on 2 environmental variables.  One PC along with other environmental variables used as predictors in multielevel bayesian models.
notes: "Ln‐transformed TDN and TDP were strongly correlated, so we used principal component analysis to reduce them into a single principal component that explained 92% of their covariation."

citation: Bestová, H., Munoz, F., Svoboda, P., Škaloud, P., & Violle, C. (2018). Ecological and biogeographical drivers of freshwater green algae biodiversity: from local communities to large-scale species pools of desmids. Oecologia, 186(4), 1017–1030. doi:10.1007/s00442-018-4074-x
pca_use: PCA space used to create distance-based variable
description: PCA on WorldClim data. 2 PCs used to measure euclidean environmental distance between communities.  In addition, used PLS with the full set of WorldClim variables as predictors.

citation: Hinman, E. D., & Fridley, J. D. (2018). To spend or to save? Assessing energetic growth-storage tradeoffs in native and invasive woody plants. Oecologia, 188(3), 659–669. doi:10.1007/s00442-018-4177-4
description: PLS used to predict nonstructural carbohydrates from near infrared data using a model trained by the authors. PCA on 3 variables (one of which is categorical, with two levels).  Resulting two PCs used as predictors in MANOVA.
notes: The authors lose a lot of information about the variables by doing PCA and using PCs as inputs to a multivariate test that could have instead used the raw variables.

citation: Wilson, J. K., Woods, H. A., & Kessler, A. (2018). High levels of abiotic noise in volatile organic compounds released by a desert perennial: implications for the evolution and ecology of airborne chemical communication. Oecologia, 188(2), 367–379. doi:10.1007/s00442-018-4225-0
description: Multivariate analyses on concentrations of 19 compunds.  PCA used to confirm results of MANOVA and LDA.
notes: Using PCA to confirm results of a supervised test may be inapropriate if variables that co-vary with the response do not contribute greatly to overal variation in the data.

citation: Chauvin, K. M., Asner, G. P., Martin, R. E., Kress, W. J., Wright, S. J., & Field, C. B. (2018). Decoupled dimensions of leaf economic and anti-herbivore defense strategies in a tropical canopy tree community. Oecologia, 186(3), 765–782. doi:10.1007/s00442-017-4043-9
description: PCA on 8 plant traits and PCoA on 11 plant traits.  Used to describe major axes of trait variation among species.

citation: Thomson, J. A., Whitman, E. R., Garcia-Rojas, M. I., Bellgrove, A., Ekins, M., Hays, G. C., & Heithaus, M. R. (2018). Individual specialization in a migratory grazer reflects long-term diet selectivity on a foraging ground: implications for isotope-based tracking. Oecologia, 188(2), 429–439. doi:10.1007/s00442-018-4218-z
description: PCA on diet of turtles (three possible foods).  Two PCs interpreted used in regressions as predictors.
notes: In the methods, the authors say the PCs were interpretable, but it seems this interpretation is actually a result of the regressions they do

citation: Kergunteuil, A., Descombes, P., Glauser, G., Pellissier, L., & Rasmann, S. (2018). Plant physical and chemical defence variation along elevation gradients: a functional trait-based approach. Oecologia, 187(2), 561–571. doi:10.1007/s00442-018-4162-y
description: PCA on 7 comunity weighted means of plant traits. Bi-plot of two PCs used to describe functional differences along elevation.  Additionally, each trait is used in a separate regression against elevation.
notes: The focus of the paper is determining what plant traits vary with elevation.  This would be best answered with a supervised approach.

citation: Munubi, R. N., McIntyre, P. B., & Vadeboncoeur, Y. (2018). Do grazers respond to or control food quality? Cross-scale analysis of algivorous fish in littoral Lake Tanganyika. Oecologia, 188(3), 889–900. doi:10.1007/s00442-018-4240-1
description: PCA on 7 algal composition metrics. 2 PCs used as predictors in regressions.

citation: Curtis, E. M., Knight, C. A., & Leigh, A. (2018). Intracanopy adjustment of leaf-level thermal tolerance is associated with microclimatic variation across the canopy of a desert tree (Acacia papyrocarpa). Oecologia, 189(1), 37–46. doi:10.1007/s00442-018-4289-x
pca_use: PC(s) used in LM, PC(s) used in ANOVA
description: PCA with oblique rotation on 3 microlcimactic variables.  One PC used as a predictor in ANOVA and linear regression.
notes: Oblique rotation means resulting PCs are not orthogonal (the result of varimax rotation), but can be correlated.

citation: Cheynel, L., Douhard, F., Gilot-Fromont, E., Rey, B., Débias, F., Pardonnet, S., … Lemaître, J.-F. (2018). Does body growth impair immune function in a large herbivore? Oecologia, 189(1), 55–68. doi:10.1007/s00442-018-4310-4
description: PCA on 12 immune traits.  Used to look for main axes of variation in immune traits.  PERMANOVA used to test for relationship between growth rate and immune traits.
notes: They converted growth rate into a binary categorical variable (slowest vs fastest growers) which is uneccessary for PERMANOVA and results in lost information.

citation: Zhao, T., Villéger, S., & Cucherousset, J. (2018). Accounting for intraspecific diversity when examining relationships between non-native species and functional diversity. Oecologia, 189(1), 171–183. doi:10.1007/s00442-018-4311-3
pca_use: unsupervised (supervised question), PC(s) used in PERMANOVA
description: PCA on 16 functional traits. 4 PCs used to build a "functional space".  Used for variance partitioning to determine how much variance is due to inter and intraspecific differences in this trait space. PCs used in PERMANOVA.

citation: Zhou, Z., Ollinger, S. V., & Lepine, L. (2018). Landscape variation in canopy nitrogen and carbon assimilation in a temperate mixed forest. Oecologia, 188(2), 595–606. doi:10.1007/s00442-018-4223-2
description: PLS used to predict nitrogen from remote sensing data.  Authors trained a model using data they collected and used the model to predict nitrogen for other plots.

citation: Ng, K., Barton, P. S., Blanchard, W., Evans, M. J., Lindenmayer, D. B., Macfadyen, S., … Driscoll, D. A. (2018). Disentangling the effects of farmland use, habitat edges, and vegetation structure on ground beetle morphological traits. Oecologia, 188(3), 645–657. doi:10.1007/s00442-018-4180-9
description: PCA on 12 trait variables.  PC2, PC3, and PC4 used in fourth-corner analysis.
notes: Table 2 describes all the statistical analyses for the paper. Unclear why all 12 trait variables aren't used in fourth-corner analysis directly, but we are not very familiar with this technique.

citation: Humphrey, P. T., Gloss, A. D., Frazier, J., Nelson–Dittrich, A. C., Faries, S., & Whiteman, N. K. (2018). Heritable plant phenotypes track light and herbivory levels at fine spatial scales. Oecologia, 187(2), 427–445. doi:10.1007/s00442-018-4116-4
description: PCA on 4 plant triats. PC1 and PC2 used separately as resposne variables in linear mixed effects models.  This method was repeated on the concentration of 8 glucosinolates.
notes: Authors do an excellent job justifying their methods. However, this experimental design might have been a good candidate for partial RDA.

citation: Varzinczak, L. H., Moura, M. O., Lima, C. S., & Passos, F. C. (2018). How do bat, rodent, and marsupial communities respond to spatial and environmental gradients? Insights from a deconstruction of mammal beta diversity from the Atlantic Forest of South America. Oecologia, 189(4), 851–861. doi:10.1007/s00442-018-4288-y
pca_use: PCA space used to create distance-based variable
description: PCA on 8 environmental variables.  PCs used to calculate pairwise euclidean distances among species. Used the resulting matrix in a Mantel test.
notes: "To circumvent the multicollinearity between environmental variables, we summarized environmental data in a principal component analysis (PCA)"

citation: Ruocco, M., Marín-Guirao, L., Ravaglioli, C., Bulleri, F., & Procaccini, G. (2018). Molecular level responses to chronic versus pulse nutrient loading in the seagrass Posidonia oceanica undergoing herbivore pressure. Oecologia, 188(1), 23–39. doi:10.1007/s00442-018-4172-9
description: PERMANOVA on expression of 19 genes of interest as a response.  PCA used for visualizing results of PERMANOVA
notes: PCA is unsupervised and may not pick up on the same variables as PERMANOVA.  RDA might have been a better option here because it is supervised and produces principal component axes.

citation: Aranguren-Riaño, N. J., Guisande, C., Shurin, J. B., Jones, N. T., Barreiro, A., & Duque, S. R. (2018). Amino acid composition reveals functional diversity of zooplankton in tropical lakes related to geography, taxonomy and productivity. Oecologia, 187(3), 719–730. doi:10.1007/s00442-018-4130-6
description: PCA on physical and chemical conditions in lakes. PC1 interpreted as "trophic status" and used as predictor in regression.  For a separate analysis, linear discriminant analysis (supervised) is used to test for separation of locations and taxa by amino acid composition.
notes: "Associations among the different aspects of the physical and chemical environment of the lakes were analyzed by principal components analysis (PCA)."

citation: Wigley, B. J., Fritz, H., & Coetsee, C. (2018). Defence strategies in African savanna trees. Oecologia, 187(3), 797–809. doi:10.1007/s00442-018-4165-8
description: PCA on 4 soil variables. Clustering in PCA space used to identify different soil types. Used k-means clustering and LDA to determine if there were groupings in plant trait space.
notes: "To test whether our sites diverged in terms of nutrient status, we used soil P, soil N, soil C:N, and SB in a principal component analysis (PCA). "  PCA, being an unsupervised analysis, can't do this.

citation: Hopley, T., & Byrne, M. (2018). Connectivity in riparian plants: influence of vegetation type and habitat fragmentation overrides water flow. Oecologia, 188(2), 465–478. doi:10.1007/s00442-018-4226-z
description: DAPC and spatial PCA on 30,000+ SNPs.  DAPC is PCA followed by LDA using PC axes as predictors.
notes: According to the documentation for the DAPC function they used, this is PCA followed by LDA on some number of principal components.  So this is essentially equivalent to a principal component regression with a categorical response and multiple PCs as predictors. Because of the large number of SNPs and because researchers aren't interested in specific SNPs, this seems entirely justified.

citation: Siegert, C. M., Clay, N. A., Tang, J. D., Garrigues, L. G., & Riggins, J. J. (2018). Indirect effects of bark beetle-generated dead wood on biogeochemical and decomposition processes in a pine forest. Oecologia, 188(4), 1209–1226. doi:10.1007/s00442-018-4283-3
description: PCA used to visualize and confirm results of PERMANOVA
notes: PCA is unsupervised and may not pick up on the same variables as PERMANOVA.  RDA might have been a better option here because it is supervised and produces principal component axes.

citation: Symons, C. C., Schulhof, M. A., Cavalheri, H. B., & Shurin, J. B. (2018). Antagonistic effects of temperature and dissolved organic carbon on fish growth in California mountain lakes. Oecologia, 189(1), 231–241. doi:10.1007/s00442-018-4298-9
description: PCA on 2 indices of disolved organic carbon quality. PC2 used as predictor in linear regressions along with 9 other variables.
notes: PCA explicitly used to deal with multicollinearity

citation: Jiang, F., Xun, Y., Cai, H., & Jin, G. (2018). Functional traits can improve our understanding of niche- and dispersal-based processes. Oecologia, 186(3), 783–792. doi:10.1007/s00442-018-4060-3
pca_use: PCA space used to create distance-based variable
description: PCA used to reduce trait redundancy.  5 PCs used in a multivariable trait dendrogram, which, in turn, was used to generate a trait distance matrix between species. Additionally, partial RDA used for hypothesis testing.

citation: Ramírez-Bautista, A., & Williams, J. N. (2018). The importance of productivity and seasonality for structuring small rodent diversity across a tropical elevation gradient. Oecologia, 190(2), 275–286. doi:10.1007/s00442-018-4287-z
description: PCA on habitat, climate, and productivity variables.  Used to select orthogonal predictor variables for linear regressions.

citation: Sena, P. H. A., Lins-e-Silva, A. C. B., & Gonçalves-Souza, T. (2018). Integrating trait and evolutionary differences untangles how biodiversity affects ecosystem functioning. Oecologia, 188(4), 1121–1132. doi:10.1007/s00442-018-4269-1
description: Discriminant analysis of principal components (DAPC, PCA followed by LDA using principal components as variables) on functional and phylogenetic distance measures.  Used to check if plots were as functionally and phylogenetically diverse as they were intended to be in the experimental design.
notes: "To double check if selected species were functionally and phylogenetically distant (or close), we visualized them into a multidimensional space (obtained from phylogenetic/functional distances) with a Discriminant Analysis of Principal Components (DAPC, from adegenet R package; Jombart et al. 2008). "

citation: Grman, E., Zirbel, C. R., Bassett, T., & Brudvig, L. A. (2018). Ecosystem multifunctionality increases with beta diversity in restored prairies. Oecologia, 188(3), 837–848. doi:10.1007/s00442-018-4248-6
description: PCA on 5+ soil variables. PC used as predictor in SEM

citation: Rota, T., Jabiol, J., Chauvet, E., & Lecerf, A. (2018). Phenotypic determinants of inter-individual variability of litter consumption rate in a detritivore population. Oikos, 127(11), 1670–1678. doi:10.1111/oik.05228
description: PCA of "warp scores" from morphometric analysis. Used to visualize and confirm results from PERMANOVA.
notes: "We visualised correlations among traits and similarities among individuals using a principal component analysis (PCA). To prevent the influence of trivial correlations on PCA results, we specified sheltering RD and velocity × movement RD as supplementary rather than active variables. "

citation: Ousterhout, B. H., & Semlitsch, R. D. (2018). Effects of conditionally expressed phenotypes and environment on amphibian dispersal in nature. Oikos, 127(8), 1142–1151. doi:10.1111/oik.05276
description: PCA on 7 morphological traits. Used as a predictor in quantile regression.

citation: Guiz, J., Ebeling, A., Eisenhauer, N., Hacker, N., Hertzog, L., Oelmann, Y., … Hillebrand, H. (2018). Interspecific competition alters leaf stoichiometry in 20 grassland species. Oikos, 127(7), 903–914. doi:10.1111/oik.04907
pca_use: unsupervised, PCA space used to create distance-based variable, PC(s) used in correlation test
description: PCA on at least 6 functional traits.  Used to select plants that spanned a range of functional space for use in an experiment. 2 PCs used to calculate pairwise distances between plant species.  PCs used in corelation tests.

citation: Jacquemyn, H., Gielen, M., & Brys, R. (2018). Is sexual organ reciprocity related to legitimate pollen deposition in distylous Pulmonaria (Boraginaceae)? Oikos, 127(8), 1216–1224. doi:10.1111/oik.05122
description: PCA on 7 floral traits.

citation: Broeckhoven, C., Mouton, P. L. le F. N., & Hui, C. (2018). Proximate causes of variation in dermal armour: insights from armadillo lizards. Oikos, 127(10), 1449–1458. doi:10.1111/oik.05401
pca_use: PC(s) used in spatial autoregressive model
description: PCA on 14 WorldClim variables. 2 PCs interpreted and used in spatial autoregressive model.

citation: Wiggins, W. D., & Wilder, S. M. (2018). Mismatch between dietary requirements for lipid by a predator and availability of lipid in prey. Oikos, 127(7), 1024–1032. doi:10.1111/oik.04766
description: PCA on 3 measures of spider size.  PC1 used response in ANOVA

citation: Valdés, A., & Ehrlén, J. (2018). Direct and plant trait-mediated effects of the local environmental context on butterfly oviposition patterns. Oikos, 127(6), 825–833. doi:10.1111/oik.04909
description: PCA on 3 plant traits. PC1 used as predictor in linear mixed models and generalized linear mixed models (binomial) as part of stuctural equation modeling.

citation: Salo, T., Räsänen, K., Stamm, C., Burdon, F. J., & Seppälä, O. (2018). Simultaneous exposure to a pulsed and a prolonged anthropogenic stressor can alter consumer multifunctionality. Oikos, 127(10), 1437–1448. doi:10.1111/oik.05310
description: PCA on 4 nutrient concentrations separately before and after a treatment. PC1 used as one of 9 response variables in PERMANOVA
notes: Authors reduced soil nutrient data dimensionallity specifically to avoid collinearity.  However, this is generally not necessary for PERMANOVA.

citation: Balmer, A. J., Brakefield, P. M., Brattström, O., & van Bergen, E. (2018). Developmental plasticity for male secondary sexual traits in a group of polyphenic tropical butterflies. Oikos, 127(12), 1812–1821. doi:10.1111/oik.05291
description: PCA on 4 wing pattern measurements. PC1 transformed into a categorical variable and used as a factor in ANOVA.

citation: Do Nascimento, E. R., Correia, I., Ruiz-Esparza, J. M., & Gouveia, S. F. (2018). Disentangling phylogenetic from non-phylogenetic functional structure of bird assemblages in a tropical dry forest. Oikos, 127(8), 1177–1185. doi:10.1111/oik.04910
pca_use: PC(s) used in variance partitioning model
description: PCA on 10 diet sources. PCA on 8 habitat traits. 3 diet PCs and 4 habitat PCs used in variance partitioning models

citation: Souto-Vilarós, D., Vuleta, A., Jovanović, S. M., Budečević, S., Wang, H., Sapir, Y., & Imbert, E. (2018). Are pollinators the agents of selection on flower colour and size in irises? Oikos, 127(6), 834–846. doi:10.1111/oik.04501
description: PCA on 4 floral morphology traits. PC1 and PC1^2 used in linear regression.

citation: Bertel, C., Rešetnik, I., Frajman, B., Erschbamer, B., Hülber, K., & Schönswetter, P. (2018). Natural selection drives parallel divergence in the mountain plant Heliosperma pusillum s.l. Oikos, 127(9), 1355–1367. doi:10.1111/oik.05364
description: PCA not mentioned in methods.  The caption of figure 5 indicates that "size" is a principal component, but unclear if this PC was used in other analyses.
